div.head: The Tape–Recorded Interview: A Manual for Field Workers in Folklore and Oral History. Revised edition. By Edward D. Ives. ( Knoxville : University of Tennessee Press, 1980. Pp. xiv, 130. Notes, illustrations, appendix, bibliography, index. Paperbound, $5.50.)

From Memory to History: Using Oral Sources in Local Historical Research. By Barbara Allen and William Lynwood Montell. ( Nashville : American Association for State and Local History, 1981. Pp. xii, 172. Notes, appendixes, bibliography, index. $12.50.)
div.p: Since the mid-1960s the practice of oral history has experienced remarkable growth, chiefly (but not exclusively) among groups and individuals who are not associated with the academic world. Oral history is said to be particularly useful in the retrieval of local history and of the history and experiences of minorities, of immigrant groups, of labor, and of that overwhelming majority of mankind that is systematically ignored in more traditional forms of research. Many claim to be "doing oral history"; the historical societies, libraries, high schools, and colleges that have oral history projects are numerous. Just as numerous are the definitions of the activity. Neither of the books under consideration contributes to any clarification of "oral history," but both offer valuable insight into the general process of recording and collecting information from oral sources.

Edward D. Ives has written a useful manual that includes concise and informative chapters on interviewing and the processing of interviews. Of particular worth is his proposition that the most effective interview is the one consciously conducted as
a trialogue, with the recorder as the third party. In the choice of recorder, however, Ives makes some dubious assertions supporting reel-to-reel equipment operated in its battery-powered mode. The modern cassette recorder compares favorably to the reel-to-reel in portability, reliability, and in reproduction of human speech, and some of the best can be had for one tenth the price of a Uher 4000. Certainly Ives has had great success with his equipment and techniques, but for reasons related primarily to expense and utility the average project would be well advised to use cassette recorders.

While Ives addresses the problems and the potential of the tape-recorded interview exclusively, Allen and Montell broaden the scope of their attention to include any oral expression, whether taped or not. From Memory to History is a rationale for the collection of "orally communicated history" on the local level, accompanied by suggestions for identification and analysis of the information so collected. As early as page three the authors have made it clear that they really mean oral tradition when they refer to orally communicated history. Confusing terminology notwithstanding, they make a strong case for increased attention to lore and tradition in the research and writing of local histories.

It is this theme of oral communication as a source of lore and tradition that From Memory to History and The Tape-Recorded Interview have in common, and both books handle the theme capably. Readers interested in recording other, perhaps equally enlightening, versions of the past have recourse to several excellent works cited in the bibliographies. Both books are by folklorists; consequently, it is not surprising that neither has much to offer on the subject of the taped, oral account as a primary source in the understanding and writing of history. Instead, "oral history" and "orally communicated history" are charged with folkloric meaning, accompanied by the required expressions of "non-elitist" orientation (Ives, p. xii) and "what people believe happened is often as important as what actually happened" (Allen, Montell, p. 89).

Most oral history projects in Indiana are engaged primarily in efforts to determine and understand the reality of the past at the local and state level. Often, researchers already know what people believe happened; they would like to find out what actually happened. Ives's, Allen's, and Montell's interests lie elsewhere.

div.head: Books in American History: A Basic List for High Schools and Junior Colleges. By John E. Wiltz; second edition by Nancy C. Cridland. ( Bloomington : Indiana University Press, 1981. Pp. xii, 113. Index. Clothbound, $12.95; paperbound, $5.95.)
div.p: Bibliographies are needed for all levels of libraries and teaching. This volume is a revision of John E. Wiltz's 1964 publication, one of the few written for the high school and junior college. Although Nancy C. Cridland attempted to retain as many titles as possible, the changes in publishing cause a nearly 50 percent turnover. Reflecting the flow of professional interests, books dealing with women, Chicanos, native Americans, and environmental works are now included, and black history is expanded. Where possible, paperbacks have been favored, and a small amount of historical fiction is now listed. New is a brief chapter on reference and review sources for nonprint media.

Composed of under four hundred titles, the work is similar in length to the bibliographies of high school textbooks but has better annotations, lists more paperbacks, and is easier to use. Some textbooks, however, give more information about reading level. Use as a checklist for the librarian, concerned parent, or school board member is facilitated by the chapter "One Hundred Selected Titles." Both editions, if followed, would create a rich library for American history students.

A few minor errors were noted. The Growth of the American Republic is now authored by Samuel Eliot Morison, Henry S. Commager, and William E. Leuchtenburg. Frederick Bancroft, not Thomas A., wrote Slave Trading in the Old South. One book that is listed is already out of print. Because of the fleeting nature of paperbacks, prospective users should probably purchase the cheaper version of this book and hope that fewer than seventeen years pass before a new edition appears.

div.p:
The Calumet Region: An Historical Resource Guide. Compiled by Lance Trusty, for the Regional Studies Institute of Purdue University Calumet. ( Hammond , Ind.: Purdue Research Foundation, 1980. Pp. 63. $1.75, from Calumet Campus Shop, Purdue University Calumet, Hammond , Indiana 46323.) Every corner of Indiana should be so lucky! Lance Trusty's guide to the Calumet Region is an unmatched aid to the local historian. Trusty lists the libraries, archives, and historical societies in the Calumet and indicates the nature and special features of their local history collections. He includes also a good list of theses, dissertations, and research papers and a bibliography of published accounts, organized by subject. Not only is the guide the essential starting point for every researcher, it is also testimony to the vitality and excitement of local history in Indiana's most varied and perhaps most interesting area. James H. Madison, Indiana University, Bloomington
.

The Brown County Book. By Bill Thomas. ( Bloomington : Indiana University Press, 1981. Pp. 96. Illustrations, map. Clothbound, $17.95; paperbound, $7.95.) Widely known and widely traveled photojournalist Bill Thomas has produced a beautiful book about Brown County , Indiana, where he resides. Excellent photographs feature the spectacular scenery of the southern Indiana hills, closeups of wildlife in its natural habitat, contemporary craftsmen at work, and the native Brown Countians themselves. An accompanying text focuses on humorist Kin Hubbard, photographer Frank M. Hohenberger, and artist Theodore C. Steele, all of whom earlier recognized the potential of rustic Brown County and used it in their work. Also included are descriptions of the traditions, legends, crafts, music, even the food, complete with recipes. Thomas depended heavily on other authors for his sections on Hubbard, Hohenberger, and Steele; most Hoosiers will realize that the scenic photographs are typical of much of southern Indiana, not just Brown County ; and many natives may wish that some of the more contemporary "legends" had been omitted; but this is a beautiful book that residents of and visitors to the county will appreciate. Lorna Lutes Sylvester, Indiana University, Bloomington
.

Trails to Hoosier Heritage. By Harry G. Black. ( Hammond , Ind.: HMB Publications, 1981. Pp. 99. Maps, illustrations, bibliography. Paperbound, $3.95, plus $.50 postage.) Trails to Hoosier Heritage is a compact collection of sketches that samples
Indiana's historical sites, events, and personalities. The Hammond , Indiana, author elicits from his statewide odyssey thirty-six profiles geographically organized into northern, central, and southern sections. Black rehearses the familiar, but he obviously prefers the romantic byways. Obscure caverns, crumbling foundations, half-deserted settlements, or secluded cemeteries provide focal points for legends of lost treasure, accounts of former boom towns, failed enterprises, and human tragedies. A concluding essay surveys the state's pioneer era. Explicit instructions are given for reaching the attractions. Maps and photographs further enhance the text. Robert M. Taylor, Jr., Indiana Historical Society, Indianapolis
.

My Lifelong Pursuit of Lincoln. By R. Gerald McMurtry. ( Fort Wayne , Ind.: Louis A. Warren Lincoln Library and Museum, 1981. Pp. 127. Illustrations, notes, bibliography. Free upon request.) R. Gerald McMurtry has devoted his life's work to the study of Abraham Lincoln and especially to the acquisition of Lincoln manuscripts and memorabilia. As director of the Lincoln Library and Museum in Fort Wayne from 1956 to 1972 McMurtry did much to further the cause of Lincoln scholarship, not only in acquiring source materials but in editing Lincoln Lore, speaking to audiences throughout the United States and overseas, and writing books and articles (listed in the bibliography of this publication). His memoirs are delightful reading, sprinkled with humor and human interest, and they provide good insights into important components of popular and scholarly history and the blending of the two. James H. Madison, Indiana University, Bloomington
.

The Quilt Chronicles: A Montgomery County Heritage, 1821–1979. By Martha Cantrell. ( Crawfordsville , Ind.: Montgomery County Historical Society and Crawfordsville Art League, 1979. Pp. 147. Illustrations, annotations and bibliography. $10.00.) In June, 1976, 125 women from Montgomery County , Indiana, completed a Bicentennial Quilt composed of forty-two blocks that depicted sites and symbols related to the 150-year history of the county. Each contributor chose her own design, and no particular effort was made to coordinate the selections. Amazingly, all four seasons, each decade between 1821 and 1979, and all facets of Montgomery County 's socio-economic structure were included. The Quilt Chronicles provides a historical narrative for each of the quilt blocks. Like the quilt itself, the chronicles are "not intended as definitive
history" but only as "sketches which present images of what has happened in Montgomery County since 1821" (introduction). Recognizing that "all is not known, nor probably ever will be" (introduction), Martha Cantrell has nonetheless written an interesting, informative, and well-researched account of Montgomery County as depicted by the Bicentennial Quilt. She, the quiltmakers, and all others connected with the project are to be commended for their unique contribution to Indiana history. Lorna Lutes Sylvester, Indiana University, Bloomington
.

Catalogue of an Exhibit on the Private Press of the Indiana Kid (James Lamar Weygand): Pioneer of Private Press Printing in Indiana with a Complete Bibliography of His Works. Compiled by Anton C. Masin. ([Nappanee, Ind.: Private Press of the Indiana Kid], with the support of the Friends of the Library at Notre Dame, 1981. Pp. xiii, [26].) Private press printing, according to the introduction to this pamphlet, "is a mostly noncommercial attempt at fine bookmaking with a personal touch essentially for aesthetic satisfaction without a primary profit motive" (p. ix). The private press movement began in England in the 1890s and has spread throughout the world. James Lamar Weygand, who lives in Nappanee, Indiana, and who prints under the name of the Indiana Kid, produced his first booklet—a letter written by Booth Tarkington—in 1944 on a 3 × 5 Kelsey Excelsior platen hand press. Almost forty years and a number of presses later he is still privately printing a variety of items, several on quality paper that he produces himself. As the title indicates, this pamphlet is a catalog of an exhibit that was held at the University of Notre Dame Memorial Library on the private press of the Indiana Kid. Although the exhibit concluded in December, 1981, the pamphlet contains a bibliography of the Indiana Kid's publications, including several miniature books. Lorna Lutes Sylvester, Indiana University, Bloomington
.

div.head: Recent Articles, Pamphlets, and Dissertations in Indiana History
div.p: Editor's Note. This list of articles, pamphlets, and dissertations published in 1980 and 1981 is intended as a bibliographic contribution to Indiana's history. As our first list of this kind, it is neither complete nor systematic in coverage. With this first effort as an experiment we hope to be able to present a list in each March issue of the Indiana Magazine of History. Readers can help in this objective by sending items for possible inclusion. We are especially interested in listing publications that make some contribution to understanding Indiana's past but are not normally reviewed in the IMH. Generally, we will not list newspaper articles or accounts of local historical society activities (which are reported in the Indiana History Bulletin), but printed pamphlets as well as journal articles may be listed. All such items for the March, 1983, issue must be received by December 1, 1982. Many people have contributed to the present list, but major responsibility has rested with Robert G. Barrows of the Indiana Historical Bureau and Gary L. Bailey of the Indiana Magazine of History.
